Question: A researcher wants to determine whether a new study method improves test scores.
She randomly assigns 100 high school students to two groups: 50 students use the new study method (treatment group), while 50 students use their regular study methods (control group).
After two weeks, all students take the same test, and the treatment group scores 8 points higher on average than the control group.
However, when analyzing the data further, the researcher discovers that the treatment group spent an average of 3 more hours studying than the control group during the two-week period.

What is the primary flaw in this experimental design, and how could the researcher modify the design to better determine whether the new study method itself (rather than study time) causes improved test scores? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out the primary flaw in this experiment and how to fix it.
Let me start by understanding what's going on here.
The researcher has 100 high school students.
She splits them into two groups: 50 use the new study method (treatment), and 50 stick with their regular methods (control).
After two weeks, all take the same test, and the treatment group scores 8 points higher on average.
That seems like a good result for the new method.
But then she finds out that the treatment group spent 3 more hours studying than the control group.
Hmm, that's interesting.
So, the treatment group both used the new method and studied longer.
The control group used their regular methods but studied less.
So, when the treatment group scored higher, it could be because of the new method, or because they studied more.
The researcher wants to know if the new method itself caused the better scores, not just the extra study time.
I think the main problem here is that the treatment group might have both the new method and more study time, making it hard to tell which factor caused the better scores.
It's like a situation where two variables are changing at the same time—so it's hard to isolate the effect of the new method.
To fix this, the researcher needs to ensure that only one thing is changing between the groups.
Maybe she should keep the study time the same for both groups.
That way, any difference in scores can be attributed solely to the new study method.
So, the primary flaw is that both groups changed in two aspects: study method and study time.
To determine if the method itself caused the improvement, she should control for study time by, say, requiring both groups to study the same number of hours.
Then, any difference in test scores would be due to the study method alone.

The primary flaw in this experimental design is that both groups experienced a change in two variables: the study method and study time.
The treatment group used the new method and studied longer, while the control group used their regular method and studied less.
This makes it impossible to determine whether the improved scores were due to the new method or the additional study time.
To fix this, the researcher should ensure that only the study method differs between the groups while keeping study time constant.
This way, any difference in test scores can be attributed solely to the new study method.
